meeting_annotations.speaker: FB
meeting_annotations.transcript: A lot of times when you think about technology advancement, you know, while direct air capture might be the ultimate goal, it's unlikely that the first technology is going to be able to go after that. Thermochemical technologies usually make a lot of hay when you're really large and can take advantage of sort of heat integration and infrastructure, right? And so, you know, one of the things is, are there applications that you could think about where electrochemical technologies or some of the things we're talking about here are uniquely positioned because I assume that in cabin capture, it's really just like, you know, alkaline pellets, right? Um, you know, Apollo 13 or something like that, right? And you know, if that's true, then the question would be, are there opportunities to kind of say, are there, can we sort of walk down the technology curve from let's say carbon capture to maybe in cabins to maybe buildings to eventually direct air capture?

meeting_annotations.speaker: JY
meeting_annotations.transcript: I have a question related to what you were saying about scale. Um, and I know some of you guys work with flow batteries too, which is probably related. Is there um an optimal scale at which to run these electrochemical processes? And is it, can you can you scale it down without any loss uh indefinitely? Like what's what what sizes matter?

meeting_annotations.speaker: FB
meeting_annotations.transcript: It depends on the process a little bit, um, and it depends upon where your cost is in the process. So, for example, you could sort of think of it as flow batteries are an easy example because you can separate power and energy. And so if you want an energy intensive application, the cost is dominated by what's in your tank. Um, if you have a power dominant application, it's dominated by what the what it cost you to make the reactor. Uh in these kind of systems, it's a bit different, right? And it would probably the way you'd want to think about it is throughput, right? So it's kind of what is the capital cost of your reactor? And then how much CO2 can you put through it because that's how you're going to make money, right? Um, and so that's how you should think about it. I mean, capital cost is important because, you know, bank ability, like someone's got to pay for the thing, right? And so if you think about like the first solar cells, they they kind of stunk, right? But they're still working and they're small and you can put them on your roof, right? Um, and so, you know, if for electrochemical systems, you could build at that sort of scale, local residential scale, and that allows you to do a lot more learning um as you go, and allows you also to make smaller products, which mean that there's less opportunities for for screw ups and a lot less money involved. Um, for a lot of sort of, you know, the larger scale systems like I guess carbon engineering, I mean, I think that system is is is pretty big in the base case. And I don't know how many of them they've built. I'm not so I've seen a lot of pretty pictures, but I don't know if I've actually seen a plant. Um, and so there's some some something about like, well, who's paying for this? How confident are you that this is going to work? Yada yada yada, this kind of stuff, right? So I don't think electrochemical systems can be infinitely small for sure. Um, but you could be a lot smaller than thermochemical systems. And actually if you look at scaling analysis, thermochemical systems can beat out electrochemical systems at large enough scale, right? Just because of heat integration, we're really good at that. Um, but at smaller scales, um the tables turn.
